subSections.subSectionTitle: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples

keyPoints.point: Australia’s first inhabitants are the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
Aboriginal people are from mainland Australia and Tasmania.
Aboriginal peoples arrived in Australia between 65,000 and 40,000 years ago.
Torres Strait Islander people are from islands between the northern tip of Queensland and Papua New Guinea.
European settlement started when the first 11 convict ships, which became known as the ‘First Fleet’, arrived from Great Britain on 26 January 1788.
The first Governor of the colony of New South Wales was Captain Arthur Phillip.
Early free settlers came from Great Britain and Ireland. This British and Irish heritage has had a major influence on Australia’s recent history, culture and politics.
In 1901, the separate colonies were united into a federation of states called the Commonwealth of Australia. This is also when the national parliament, government and the High Court were established.
In 1901, Australia’s population was about four million but this number did not include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples until a referendum to include them in 1967.
Australia’s national language is English and migrants should learn and use English to help them participate in Australian society.
Australia is made up of 6 states and 2 territories
State: New South Wales (NSW)| Capital City: Sydney
State: Victoria (Vic.) | Capital City: Melbourne
State: Queensland (Qld) | Capital City: Brisbane
State: Western Australia (WA) | Capital City: Perth
State: South Australia (SA) | Capital City: Adelaide
State: Tasmania (Tas.) | Capital City: Hobart
Territory: Australian Capital Territory (ACT) | Capital City: Canberra
Territory: Northern Territory (NT) | Capital City: Darwin
A Welcome to Country is a cultural practice performed by an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander custodian of the local region, welcoming visitors to their traditional land.

A Welcome to Country is usually the first item of proceedings to open an event and can take place through many forms, including songs, dances, smoking ceremonies or speeches in traditional language or English.

An Acknowledgement of Country is an opportunity to recognise that the gathering is on Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander land and to pay respects to Traditional Custodians and to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in attendance. Anyone can deliver an Acknowledgement of Country.

On 26 January each year, we celebrate Australia Day. Australia Day is a public holiday in every state and territory in Australia. It is the anniversary of the arrival of the First Fleet from Great Britain in 1788. During Australia Day celebrations, the Prime Minister announces the Australian of the Year Awards in Canberra.

Anzac Day is commemorated on 25 April each year.It is a solemn day when we remember the sacrifice of all Australians who served and died in wars, conficts and peacekeeping operations. Anzac Day is named after the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, which landed at Gallipoli in Turkey during World War I on 25 April 1915
The Australian National Flag is blue, white and red.
The Australian Aboriginal Flag is black, red and yellow.
The Torres Strait Islander Flag is green, blue, black and white
The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the offcial symbol of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Australia’s national fower is the golden wattle.
Australia’s national colours are green and gold.
The opal is Australia’s national gemstone.
Advance Australia Fair’ is Australia’s national anthem. It is sung on occasions of national importance, including at Australian citizenship ceremonies and major sporting events.
